awd_titl_txt: Characterization of Convective Interactions with Easterly Waves, the Caribbean Low-Level Jet and Central American Topography During OTREC
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports work on the Organization of Tropical East Pacific Convection (OTREC) field campaign.  The campaign seeks to understand the formation and development of tropical convective clouds and associated heavy rainfall in the adjacent but distinct regions of the eastern equatorial Pacific and the southwest Caribbean, along with their evolution over the intervening portions of Central America and Colombia. The campaign also examines the genesis and evolution of easterly waves, large westward-moving atmospheric disturbances (wavelengths of about 2,000 km) which occur on a weekly basis in the Caribbean and eastern Pacific. The full set of campaign awards is discoverable on the nsf.gov/awardsearch webpage by a keyword search on "OTREC".

Tropical convection plays a critical role in earth's climate system and is also responsible for extreme precipitation and hurricane formation.  Easterly waves are of particular interest for weather forecasting given their tendency to spawn hurricanes.  More generally, tropical convection is an engine of weather and climate worldwide yet poorly understood and difficult to simulate.  Work leading to better representation of tropical convection in weather and climate models can thus lead to better weather forecasts and impact assessments, both for the public and decision makers.  Aside from the societal relevance of the science, the campaign includes several education and outreach activities including support for undergraduates to participate in fieldwork and production of short documentary videos for use in classroom teaching and informal science education.  In addition, the project builds international scientific collaboration through partnerships with researchers in Costa Rica and Mexico. The project also supports fieldwork participation by three graduate students, and outreach to local students is conducted through short courses at the University of Costa Rica.

The eight week OTREC deployment consists primarily of a set of 20 flights in the Gulfstream V (GV) research aircraft maintained by the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR).  The campaign uses an airport in Costa Rica for easy access to the equatorial Pacific and southwest Caribbean study regions, and conditions in these regions are sampled using dropsondes and a wing-mounted W-band radar.  Dropsondes contain the same instrument package as standard weather balloons, only dropped from an aircraft (in this case from about 40,000 feet) with a small parachute.  The radar determines cloud properties such as the relative abundance of ice particles versus liquid droplets, and uses Doppler shift to measure updraft and downdraft speeds in clouds.  The aircraft sampling is augmented by observations collected at ground sites in Costa Rica and Colombia.

The specific focus of this project is easterly waves, which play a dominant role in the variability of tropical convection and serve as precursors for hurricane formation.  Easterly waves in the southwestern Caribbean are generally thought to propagate into the region from West Africa.  But it is not clear whether easterly waves in the eastern Pacific originate locally or reintensify after crossing Central America from the Caribbean.  Some studies suggest that formation or reintensification occurs through instabilities of strong low-level jets which occur where winds are funneled through gaps in the Central American mountains.  Generation and intensification could also happen through interaction with convection, either over Central America or off the Pacific coast of Colombia, regions where a strong diurnal cycle produces episodes of intense convection and rainfall.

The role of jet stream instabilities in generating or reinvigorating easterly waves is examined using data from meteorological analyses produced using observations from the OTREC campaign (provided by collaborators at ECMWF).  The interaction of easterly waves with convection over Central America is examined using satellite data and surface meteorology stations in Costa Rica. These include GPS receivers already deployed as part of the COCONet network (see EAR-1042906), which record the total precipitable water vapor in the atmosphere.  These assets are augmented with an additional 10 GPS ground stations and 10 surface weather stations, as well as two weather balloon launching stations. A key issue to be examined with the surface stations is the timing of the maxima in precipitable water vapor and precipitation, as the lag between the two (i.e. whether precipitation peaks first or precipitable water peaks first) provides valuable information regarding the organization and vertical structure of convection.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The observations collected by the OTREC surface meteorological and weather balloon network were used to address three main hypotheses: 1) the diurnal cycle in rainfall is both intensified or suppressed by the easterly wave environment depending on whether the convective ("active") or suppressed phase of the wave is transiting over the region; 2) the wave convective ("active") phase is dominated by isolated storms rather than mesoscale convective systems with extensive stratiform rain area and internal organization; 3) the wave vertical structure is altered by land-based rainy systems which differ from those over open ocean as the waves transit across Central America. 

We have found that easterly waves enhance the frequency of occurrence and duration of rainfall over the diurnal cycle during their "active" phase relative to "neutral" wave conditions or the "suppressed" phase, where "active" refers to the conditions when the wave circulation favors the organization of rainy systems, "neutral" refers to conditions when cloud anomalies associated with the wave are not present, and "suppressed" refers to the conditions when the wave circulations are unfavorable to the organization of rainy systems. The wave impacts on the diurnal cycle in rainfall are found to be associated with greater nighttime to early morning instability and higher precipitable water vapor during the active phase of the waves. The increase in precipitable water vapor from about 8-9 hours prior to rain onset until rain begins is largest for the active phase of the wave, indicating the presence of stronger water vapor convergence, known to be important to the organization of rainy systems in the Tropics. 

Examining the phasing of rain onset with the peak buildup of precipitable water vapor at our sites during active phases, we find that there is overall moistening of the environment following rain events. This result is consistent with an increase in isolated storms rather than mesoscale convective systems during the active phase, the idea being that isolated systems develop in relatively drier environments and serve to moisten those environments, while mesoscale convection develops in areas pre-moistened by, for example, isolated systems. A similar result is implied by reanalysis vertical velocity profiles composited for our sites and for these same active periods, which suggest elevated peak upward motion over the Caribbean Sea and East Pacific away from the coasts and mid to lower tropospheric peak upward motion over our Caribbean and Pacific balloon launch sites. Balloon peak temperature and moisture anomalies are also seen at mid-levels, consistent with the reanalyses. In addition, peak balloon temperature and reanalysis vertical motion anomalies at the Caribbean site are both elevated compared to those at the Pacific site, suggesting oceanic influences on the convective development along the Caribbean coast. Thus, the type of convection coupled to the waves appears to change as the wave troughs pass over Central America.

As the wave propagates across the country, peak rainfall shifts from morning at the Caribbean coast to late afternoon at the inland sites. The propagation of the rainfall suggests an eastward phase speed of about 4 degrees per day across Costa Rica, while the propagation of wave cloudy and rainy regions seen in satellite imagery and representative of more open ocean is estimated at closer to 10 degrees per day eastward. This suggests that the wave-diurnal cycle interactions may slow the wave active centers over the land region. 

The scientific outcomes of this study have broad implications for regional weather prediction, water management, and extreme weather disaster preparedness. In addition, they have implications for predicting non-local impacts of tropical waves on tropical and global circulations through improved understanding of wave maintenance as these disturbances pass over land areas. The outcome of this study's outreach support of several undergraduate and graduate students during the OTREC field campaign resulted in four undergraduate and three Masters students going on to use the OTREC data for their thesis work and are now entering atmospheric science degree programs or the STEM workforce. OTREC data are also being analyzed in undergraduate courses in Meteorology in both the United States and Costa Rica and in a study abroad program led by Prof. Lintner in Costa Rica for Rutgers students. The course on the use of the US hydrological model for stakeholders and academics in Costa Rica funded by the project was popular and has led to further interest in more training going forward. Finally, the project continues to nurture cooperation between US, Costa Rican, and Colombian scientists through ongoing collaborations, encouraging the next generation of scientists to advance the study of tropical weather and climate in the Americas and its global reaches.
